newsitem.title: TURKEY: Israel minister seeks manoeuvres with U.S.,Turkey.
newsitem.headline: Israel minister seeks manoeuvres with U.S.,Turkey.

text.p: Israeli Defence Minister Yitzhak Mordechai, hosting his Turkish counterpart, said he favoured joint military manoeuvres by the two countries and the United States, Turkey's Anatolian news agency said on Thursday.

"I am of the view that the three countries holding joint manoeuvres would be of great benefit as far as strengthening the countries is concerned," Mordechai was quoted by state-run Anatolian as telling Turkish reporters in Tel Aviv.
"We are making several initiatives on this subject," he said, noting that the United States already holds military operations separately with the Israeli and Turkish armies.

The visit by Turkish Defence Minister Turhan Tayan is part of increasing cooperation despite the election of Islamist Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan 16 months ago on a promise to cut growing security ties to the Jewish state.
Mordechai suggested there was further room to develop links.

"Israel, while being a small country, has many technological and scientific capabilities. It is possible to achieve very good results for the benefit of the two countries' peoples by uniting these," he said.
Tayan, from the secularist wing of Erbakan's coalition government, was to visit Israel Aircraft Industries, which is modernising Turkey's F-4 jet fighters. He is to return to Turkey on Friday.
Turkey and Israel signed defence cooperation agreements that drew objections from Iran and many in the Arab world. Israeli planes have flown training flights in Turkey under the accords.
Mordechai brushed aside opposition to the ties: "These countries are trying to ruin what is between us. My belief is that the two countries will not go along with this game."
Turkey's anti-Islamist army has pushed Erbakan's coalition with increasingly strident demands that he curb religious activism.
